isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9800 - 10 SPEED AND 15 SPEED TRANSMISSIONS EATON RT, RTO, AND RTX SERIES - REMOVE - COUNTERSHAFT BEARINGS

note.para: In the following instructions, the front and rear bearings from BOTH countershafts are removed. For removal of the mainshaft assembly from the case, it is necessary to remove the bearings from the right countershaft ONLY.

step1.para: Temporarily install the auxiliary drive gear on the mainshaft (inset, Figure 77). Remove the snap ring from each countershaft rear groove.

figure.caption: Figure 77. Remove Snap Ring From Each Countershaft Rear Groove

step1.para: Remove the six bolts from the front bearing cover ( Figure 78).

figure.caption: Figure 78. Remove Bolts From Front Bearing Cover

step1.para: Remove the front bearing cover ( Figure 79).
From inside the case, use a soft bar and maul to drive the countershaft rear bearings to the rear and from the case bores ( Figure 80).

figure.caption: Figure 80. Drive Countershaft Rear Bearings to Rear

note.para: This procedure will damage the bearings and should not be attempted unless replacement of the bearings is planned.

step1.para: Remove the bolt and front bearing retainer plate from the countershaft ( Figure 81).

figure.caption: Figure 81. Remove Bolt and Front Bearing Retainer Plate From Countershaft

step1.para: Use a soft bar and maul to drive each countershaft to the rear as far as possible ( Figure 82). This will partially unseat the front bearings.

figure.caption: Figure 82. Drive Each Countershaft to Rear

note.para: The soft bar used should have a flattened end that is large enough so as not to damage holes for the roll pin and bolt.

step1.para: From the case rear, use a soft bar and maul to drive each countershaft forward to unseat the front bearings from the case bore and expose the bearing snap ring ( Figure 83).
Use a bearing puller or pry bars to remove the countershaft front bearing ( Figure 84).

note.para: The bearing inner race will remain pressed on the countershaft.
